results.title: Lea L'hiver = Lea, in Winter
results.creator_credit: Jacques Rouffio, Francis Girod and Marc Monnet
results.brief_description:
On a Spanish island, a young French woman has died after falling from a cliff. The local police inspector is asked to solve the case quickly and quietly, so as not to disturb tourism. As the investigation seeks to find out whether this was an accidental death, a murder or a suicide, the inspector is forced to look into the long list of the victim’s lovers.

Credits: Producers, Jacques Rouffio, Francis Girod ; director, Marc Monnet ; writer, Marc Monnet ; photography, Claude Beausoleil ; music, Olivier Bloch-Laine.
Cast: Karen Blanguernon, Gilles Segal, Monique Melinand, Jean-Claude Bouillon, Hente Sonderland, Jacques Higelin, Louis Daquin.

results.title: Le Xiveme Siecle = the Xivth Century
results.brief_description:
Year 1300 represents the apex of the cultural and economical expansion of the Midle Ages with Europe being adorned by sets of new monuments in different styles: gothic in Salisbury and Reims, oriental in Palermo and Toledo. Italy is the centre of artistic innovation and production thanks to a rich class of merchant conducting business all over Europe and the Orient. From the Cathedral, the focus shifts to the city and specially the Piazza. Major works are commissined to adorn private and civil buildings, such Simone Martini’s frescos in Sienna’s Communal House. But in 1348, the Black Plague epidemic brings the artistic expansion to a grinding halt. This marks the introduction of a macabre element in art. The serene smiles of the angel on the portal of Notre Dame is no more. At the end of the XIVth century, people have two obsessions: death of the body and the unrestrained enjoyement of the short-lived pleasures of life. This episode also profiles the works of Giotto.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Le Voyage En Ballon = Stowaway in the Sky
results.brief_description:
A small child, fascinated by a lighter-than-air balloon, clambers aboard. The balloon takes flight, lifting the child upward to an amazing adventure.

Credits: Producer, Jean Velter ; director, Albert Lamorisse ; writer, Albert Lamorisse ; photography, Maurice Fellous ; music, Jean Podromides.
Cast: Pascal Lamorisse, Andre Gille, Maurice Baquet.

results.title: Le Voyage du Pere = the Father's Trip
results.creator_credit: Raymond Danon and Denys de la Patelliere
results.brief_description:
At his wife’s request, Monsieur Quentin, leaves his farm to go to city in order to convince his daughter to attend a family gathering. Once in town, he discovers that his daughter has become a prostitute.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Denys de la Patelliere ; writers, Denys de la Patelliere, Pascal Jardin ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Fernandel, Philippe Noiret, Lilli Palmer, Michel Auclair, Laurent Terzieff, Madeleine Robinson, Rosy Varte.

results.title: Le Voyage a Paimpol = the Journey to Paimpol
results.brief_description:
Maryvonne works hard in a factory and one day meets and eventually falls for an attractive Algerian co-worker. Meanwhile, the workers at the factory go on strike, and Maryvonne fantasizes that she is leading them Joan of Arc-style, or as a Russian revolutionary. When a journalist arrives to record the strike, he encourages Maryvonne to write her account of the matters at hand. The journalist is based in Paimpol, and as Maryvonne travels to meet him, her dreams and his reality are set on a collision course.

Credits: Producer, Dominique Laurent ; director, John Berry ; writers, Josiane Leveque, John Berry ; photography, Bernard Zitzerman ; music, Serge Franklin.
Cast: Myriam Boyer, Michel Boujenah, Jean-Francois Garreaud, Dora Doll, Michele Brousse.

results.title: Le Voleur de Crimes = the Crime Thief
results.brief_description:
An unhappily married man with two children watches a beautiful woman kill herself when she ties herself inside a car and drives off a cliff. Jean tries to save the woman but it is too late. After hanging out with his bohemian friends, he writes a letter to the local newspaper saying that he killed the woman. Jean is galvanized by the sensationalism of the headlines and becomes intoxicated with thoughts of murder. He does away with the pretty model and girlfriend of his painter friend in a similar manner. Soon the painter grows suspicious of Jean and believes he is the one who has sent the letters to the paper telling the story of a little man who gains self importance by murder.

Credits: Producer, Alain Queffelean ; director, Nadine Trintignant ; writer, Nadine Trintignant ; photography, Pierre Villemin ; music, Jack Arel ; assistant director, Daniel Vigne.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant ; Robert Hossein, Florinda Bolkan, Serge Marquand, Bernadette Lafont, Tanya Lopert, Georgia Moll, Karen Blanguernon, Francis Girod.

results.title: Le Vol D'icare (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Icare is the creation of a famous Parisian writer. While his master is otherwise engaged with an afternoon ‘rendez-vous’, Icare slips off the page and into the street. The writer suspecting that Icare’s flight is in fact the result of plagiarism engages dectective Morcol to try and locate the runaway hero.

Credits: Director, writer, Daniel Ceccaldi ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Michel Galabru, Caroline Cellier, Henri Garcin, Evelyne Buyle, Roger Carel, Piere Mallet.

results.title: Le Village un village
results.creator_credit: Juniper Films and Tristram Wilson Productions
results.brief_description:
A study of a typical French village community, showing day-to-day activities. Includes scenes of the market place, the school, the annual fete, and a wedding. Non-narrated.
Suitable for lower secondary levels.

results.title: Le Vieux Fusil = the Old Gun
results.brief_description:
In Montauban in 1944, Julien Dandieu works as a surgeon in the local hospital. Frightened by the German army entering Montauban, he asks his friend Francois to drive his wife and daughter to a back country village where Julien owns an old castle. One week later, Julien decides to go and join his family for the week end, but the Germans are already occupying the village. On his way to the house, Julien discovers the corpses of the villagers in the church, then, further away, the charred bodies of his daughter and his wife. He vows to personally kill every one of the Germans responsible in order to assuage his grief. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1975: Best actor for Philippe Noiret ; Best film for Robert Enrico ; Best music for Francois de Roubaix.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Caro ; director, Robert Enrico ; writer, Robert Enrico, Pascal Jardin, Claude Vieillot ; photography, Etienne Becker ; music, Francois de roubaix.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Philippe Noiret, Jean Bouise, Madeleine Ozeray, Catherine Delaporte.

results.title: Le Vieil Homme et L' Enfant = the Old Man and the Boy
results.brief_description:
During the nazi occupation of Paris, an irrepressible eight-year old jewish boy, Claude, is sent to stay with an elderly couple in the country. Since Pepe, the old man, is a rabid anti-semite, the boy is instructed to conceal his origins. Once there, Claude and Pepe forge a close relationship - beautifully realized in the playing - in which the boy is amused by the old man’s bigoted outburst and delights in provoking him, while Pepe comes to dote on the child. Berri’s film is a reconstruction of his own childhood experience and he describes it as a ‘love affair between a Jew and an anti-Semite’. Awards: Berlin Film Festival (1967): Best Actor for Michel Simon.

Credits: Director, Claude Berri ; writers, Gerard Brach, Claude Berri ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Michel Simon, Alain Cohen, Charles Denner, Luce Fabiole, Roger Carel, Paul Preboist, Zorica Lozice.
